author: {'steamid': '76561198089190959', 'num_games_owned': 1939, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1600182308}
review:
[h1] The 39 Steps [/h1]

Öncelikle bu bir point & click ya da macera oyunu değil, kitabın interaktif bir şekilde görselleştirilmiş bir adaptasyonudur ki oyun yapımcıları da aynen bu şekilde tanıtıyor. Görsel ve interaktif romanları sevdiğim için The 39 Steps'i araştırdım ve John Buchan'ın yine kendi ismindeki bir casusluk hikayesi tarzındaki (espionage thriller) kitabına dayandığını gördüm. Zaten ünlü Alfred Hitchcock da filmini bile çekmiş. Eser 1914 yani Büyük Savaş öncesi üzerine cinayet suçu yıkılmaya çalışılan ve Büyük Savaş'ın çıkmasını engellemek için uğraşan Richard Hannay'in hikayesini anlatıyor. 

Sesler muazzam ama müzikler çok zayıf. Sadece ufak melodiler var. Görsel anlatım çok güzel. Kitaba dayandırıldıdğı için seçim yapıp da hikayelerde sapmalar yapamıyorsunuz. Sadece bazı yerlerde örneğin kapıyı açarken belli şekilleri ardardına doğru bir şekilde çizerek ufak challenge'lar şeklinde kapıyı açmış oluyorsunuz. Merak etmeyin hiç zor bir yapısı yok. Sadece sizi sıkılmaktan kurtarmak için düşünülmüş sanırım ve de iyi olmuş. Karakterlerin görünüşleri ve tipleri gözükmüyor. Bu aslında güzel bir şey çünkü nasıl ki kitap okurken karakterleri kendi aklımızda canlandırıyorsak burda da insan şeklindeki beyaz silüetlerin tiplerini siz kendi hayalinizde dolduruyorsunuz. 

Olumsuz yanı olarak belki pat küt oyunlardan kazandığım İngilizce altyapısına rağmen anlamakta çok zorluk çektim. Oynarken bir elimde Google Translate bir elimde fare öyle oynadım. Ama anlayarak ilerlediğim için de zevk aldım. Yoksa ardardına tıklayıp geçecekseniz hiç almayın daha iyi. Dolayısıyla biraz İngilizce ve biraz Google Translate gerektiriyor. Eğer hiç İngilizce ile alakanız yoksa hiç tavsiye etmiyorum. Ona göre alın. 

Bu görsel romanın bazı yerlerinde donup sekmeler halinde size bilgiler veriyor ama bir süre sonra bilgi karmaşası oluyor ve 'yahu bu kimdi', 'şu nereden geldi?' gibi soruları kendi kendinize sormadan edemiyorsunuz. Süreyi kısaltmak adına yapılan bu adım bence akılları daha da bulandırmış ve okuyucuyu sıkmış. Bu ara bilgiler okuyucuya daha iyi ve etkili bir şekilde aktarılabilirdi bence.

[table]
[tr]
[th] Not [/th]
[th] 8/10 [/th]
[/tr]
[/table]

Sonu her ne kadar güzel bitse de [spoiler] kötü adamı sonradan tanıması bana saçma geldi şahsen. [/spoiler]  Sonuçta bu bir adaptasyon; kitap da aynı bu şekilde mi bilmiyorum ama [spoiler] o kadar çaba boşa gitti ve Büyük Savaş'ı engelleyemediler. Ee ne anladım bu işten. O kadar çaba, macera ve işkence bir hiç uğrunaymış. [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198101328220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1599930235}
review: I really enjoyed this. The graphical style, illustration, sound design and voice acting are all great. It probably appeals more to the bit of me that loves great radio adaptations than to the bit that loves adventure games (though having a mix of both helps). The visual novel style allows for a much more complete adaptation than film or radio usually allows for. The story is broken up into (sometimes uneven) chapters - I don't know how much this follows the original chapters of the book, but nicely breaks things down into digestible chunks. There are some interactive elements, but they are limited to clicking certain areas, or giving mouse strokes in various directions. These add interest, but the main joy is in a good story well told.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108383681', 'num_games_owned': 874, 'num_reviews': 1050, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1599393699}
review: What a great story, what a great adaptation, what a great voice acting. I know it was made with financial support, but I am even more glad it was made with support. Because otherwise this game would be another poorly made visual novel. Really good job for making this game, for recreating The 39 Steps for new audiences!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987977449', 'num_games_owned': 800, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1599383848}
review: The ultimate in linear storytelling. Excellent artwork brings the colour in a great masterpiece by John Buchan to life for a modern audience less inclined to the turning of pages. A story of 2 solo operators much like the modern James Bond of today in the moving pictures. Totally re-readable , or in this case re-playable thanks to the way the artwork is brought to life with a moving soundtrack and artfully placed sound effects along with intermittent narration. Be transported back to 1914, and a very different Britain, although maybe not that different, you be the judge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139791883', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1598392597}
review:
This "game" [strike]is[/strike] was the first on my list, which I received from Shado' almost exactly 5 years ago. It's a visual novel, but in the very strict sense - you are literally watching/clicking through a story. There's no puzzle or adventure aspect, it's just John Buchan's 1915 thriller adapted to be run through on a computer.

My first experience was the game launching in 1080p, black barred, on my 1440p monitor. "No matter," I thought, "I'll just change it once this intro finishes." The intro finishes, and I'm presented with a save/load screen, and no settings menu. At all. The only setting for this game is the language, although that does at least include disabling subtitles, V/O, and [i]Gaelic[/i]. A Google search later and it turns out the only way to fix the resolution is by editing the registry. So far, some... interesting technical decisions, but it did at least run at 3440x1440, 144fps with no issues.

The "gameplay" has some interesting mechanics. It borrows some point and click elements, but they're obviously very linear and mostly unnecessary; they're almost there to check you're still paying attention. It features some abstract use of the mouse to progress through the story, you have to make clockwise or anti-clockwise motions to advance/backtrack through the story text appearing on screen, or complete some quicktime-esque sections by drawing shapes to perform actions (such as opening a door). My favourite element of the game is where one character will be telling a story to another, which is condensed into a comedic animated silent film format. Some elements of the gameplay felt very unnecessary, where sections would be presented as topics on the screen, on which you'd have to click and then read through.

The story itself is set in May-June 1914, and focuses on our protagonist Richard Hannay, a bored, middle-class former mining engineer who gets caught up in the affairs of an American anti-semite. Most of the story feels very forced and [i]too[/i] unbelievable (I mean I get that it's a thriller but come on), and the fact that it's all based around a Jewish conspiracy is very much a [i]yikes[/i] - anti-semitism is only mentioned once, as one of the "biases" in Scudder's work, though, looking into this further, apparently the book does more to dismiss/criticise this element of the story, but this adaptation seems to omit that... The story progresses at reasonable pace until the end, where everything feels like it wraps up rather quickly and abruptly. I'm not sure if it's the digital adaptation or the book, but I'm not going to read it to find out.

While most of the story is presented through text on the screen, conversations are voice acted. The voice acting is good overall, though it mostly sits on the extremes of the represented accents - from very posh Imperial British, to harsh Scots, to Cockney London, guv'nor. Scotland is home for most of the story, though despite this most of the characters we meet are still very posh, received pronunciation types.

Generic spooky thriller music accompanies most of the story, though it is broken up by a sick techno breakdown in the credits - I couldn't stop laughing when the glitch noises and bass kicked in. It's a VIP remix of the main theme by Si Begg, available on their Soundcloud.

Overall, I'd say this is reasonably enjoyable if you're into the interactive storytelling thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107425936', 'num_games_owned': 3872, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1598372151}
review: Super Story Spiel, die Interaktion mit Gegenstände sowie verschiedliche Storyparts machen richtig Spaß, die kleinen Miniaktionen wie z.B. das Öffnen einer Tür macht mich glücklich.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013821234', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1598391904}
review:
Pas évident au départ d'accrocher à cette histoire interactive : le tout est en anglais avec parfois des accents à couper au couteau et le gameplay est rachitique. Mais une fois accepté le fait qu'il ne s'agit en rien d'un P&C je me suis laissée happer par cette histoire classique mais que je n'avais jamais eu l'occasion de lire. La DA est très efficace, on visite de nombreux lieux, il y a beaucoup à lire/écouter mais on peut passer les ph(r)ases de description. Les dialogues eux indispensables à la compréhension de l'histoire ne peuvent pas être éludés. Compter environ 5 heures pour finir l'histoire, collecter les cartes et les succès inhérents au soft (j'en ai raté quelques uns d'ailleurs en allant certainement un peu vite). Par contre pour les complétistes, les succès steam eux sont simplement liés à la progression.
Pour le prix à réserver pour chiller et parfaire ses accents anglais ou même tenter le jeu en gallois pourquoi pas ;)

Il ne manque plus qu'à visionner l'adaptation d'Hitchcock

author: {'steamid': '76561198017436282', 'num_games_owned': 985, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1523820099}
review: This is a very faithful rendition of the Novel. I reccomend reading that first, then giving this game a good go. Its short but very satisfying content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049823783', 'num_games_owned': 1712, 'num_reviews': 1265, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1595532250}
review:
Aventura Point & Click poco fuera de lo normal, casi pareciendose mas a una pelicula interactiva de imagenes (con nula intervencion) que a otra cosa.

La propuesta en si no estas mal, de hecho las imagenes, la ambientacion, sonidos, voces y algunos recursos visuales estan MUY buenos (como el de las siluetas o el uso del Mouse para manipular "objetos" con movimientos).

Pero el lore es muy confuso, se hace un ABUSO de las pantallas de texto y no se termina de entender nada.

Otro gran problema: solo esta En ingles.

Honestamente no le pondria ni pulgar arriba, ni pulgar abajo, no termine de entender el juego despues de casi 4 horas de jugarlo y llegar hasta el final, pienso que si hubieran puesto mas empeño en pulir el lore, seria un juego bastante decente.

5.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198042858126', 'num_games_owned': 1336, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1597094160}
review: Eine Warnung an alle Spieler. Drückt auf keinen Fall ESC. Ich habe mir das Intro gerade 10x angeschaut.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031038796', 'num_games_owned': 1045, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1596821855}
review:
As others already said, this is not game, remember that. If you are up for a good story, although at least for me with a little bit underwhelming ending, to go though in 4.5 hrs, go for it.
The good: 
- the story
- voice acting
- art style, obviously subjective
- nice and clean UI, designed with KISS principles 
- bookmarks mechanics
- short chapters

The average:
- ending
- music is lacking

The bad:
- virtually no options to customize the look & feel (but this is rather understandable taking into account design choices)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972566358', 'num_games_owned': 1866, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1596077807}
review: I'd recommend this for people if they know what they are getting into. It's not a game, it's a visual and audio experience of a novel. It has less choice than what you would expect from a visual novel, it's basically just a click to proceed 'game.' The espionage in the start of WWI story is pretty decent and the artwork is interesting. The acting is pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214084811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1595988625}
review: The 39 Steps is a visual novel that is based on an actual novel. I have not read the book so I do not know how well the adaption translates. The controls are basic but explained well enough. The developers tried to add as much interaction as they could. Even so, this is mostly a click and receive more text game. The story itself is quite fascinating. The delivery both visually and audibly is superb. Everything seems as though it was hand-painted. The voices were instrumental in making this story come to life. There were even a few old-timey mini-movies. They were my favorite part. If you want to relax for an afternoon with a mix of a visual novel and audiobook grab your favorite bottle of wine (or a few ;) and taking part in a conspiracy just before the first world war.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121913723', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1281, 'last_played': 1595605004}
review: 原著书评价也就那样，基于书创作的游戏表现也是同样平平无奇，而且几乎没有互动基本只能算是个有图有声读物。音乐和美术确实用心还原了，不过想获得紧张刺激的体验建议跨过游戏和书直接看1935年版本电影吧，里边Scudder不仅性转了还是个肤白貌美大长腿的大美女，希区柯克执导哦，希区柯克真的很懂怎么改编原著。The original book review is mediocre, and the game based on the book's creation is also unremarkable. It lacks almost any interaction and can only be considered as a multimedia e-book with pictures and sounds.The music and art are indeed carefully crafted, but if you want to experience the tension and excitement, it is recommended to skip the game and book altogether and watch the 1935 film adaptation. In the movie, Scudder not only undergoes a gender transformation but is also a fair-skinned and beautiful woman with long legs. Directed by Hitchcock, who really knows how to adapt the original work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029204948', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1595426216}
review: Does not work with dual monitors

author: {'steamid': '76561197968652342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1404766530}
review:
I've read the original book, and I found this "game" to be a superior way of experiencing The 39 Steps. It brings more life to the story with excellent pictures and narration, and a little bit of interactivity.

Even if you don't care for the the time period or for old British novels, it still makes for an interesting thriller with lots of twists and turns.

This is a visual novel and not a game. A lot of the people leaving bad reviews seem to be expecting it to be something more than that, but it isn't supposed to be. It's just a story with some bells and whistles. If that's want you want, you'll like The 39 Steps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198827619300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1594130701}
review:
Novela visual con interacciones y cinemáticas, que contiene una historia enigmática y bien construida que te mantiene en la intriga hasta el final.
Como no podía ser de otra forma los escenarios están muy bien hechos, con muchos detalles, muy coloridos y totalmente acordes con las diferentes situaciones de la historia.
Por último pero no menos importante el estilo que tiene con las cinemáticas en forma de película antigua y las voces y las distintas maneras de hablar según la clase social de los personajes solo puede meterte mas en el mundo que intenta recrear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002637002', 'num_games_owned': 775, 'num_reviews': 353, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1590623476}
review:
Keeping in mind this is not so much of a game, as a visual novel or digital audio/visual book version of a classic novel, it is worth "playing" through to experience that well told story. It's visually well put together, though most of the interactive parts feels quite gimicky; The gameplay is this title's weakest point.

The voice acting is mostly quite good, as is the art and overall visuals used.

There's quite a bit of text you'll need to read throughout the story though. It feels a bit of an odd choice as I imagine the main appeal of this sort of title would be as an alternative to reading the book - similar to listening to an audio book instead. This title feels more like it can't decide on one thing, however, and instead of going fully with the audio visual storytelling, it keeps a lot of the story in text form. And while I didn't particularly mind, I also enjoy reading books in general.

Some bugs are also present, such as dialogue playing twice on top of each other with a delay. However, it's not much, and shouldn't spoil too much of the experience.

All in all though, it's a good way to experience a good story. Just don't expect any proper gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021432764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1590219089}
review:
THIS IS NOT A GAME! Don't mistake it as such.

As the product description says, this is a visual novel. You do a lot of clicking and reading and very, very little "playing". Even that's not really the right word because your interaction with the story is clicking on glowing sections of pictures to get more information.

The only real "game"-iness of this is that you sometimes have to use your mouse to "draw" on the screen in a pattern the novel gives you (draw an up arrow, down arrow, left arrow, clockwise circle, etc).

Having said all that simply by way of warning, the novel is presented very well and in-depth. The story is excellent, the art is phenomenal, and the "extras" are also pretty neat to see. I don't know that I'd pay $5 for it, but if you can get it on sale, do it. If you like the novel the story is based on, full price probably isn't a bad deal either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102898526', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1590256377}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027792817', 'num_games_owned': 1081, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1587785180}
review: 39 steps to finish this

author: {'steamid': '76561198064392148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1587663707}
review:
"Thirty-nine steps... high-tide 10.17 pm"

The 39 steps is a "digital adaptation" of the book from John Buchan, telling the story of Richard Hannay who found himself brought amid a conspiracy during the spring of 1914. 
The story is cleverly told through some of the book excerpts, beautifully hand-drawn illustrations, newspaper articles, letters, character/objects cards, short silent movies and simple mini-games. And the least we can say, is that this is remarkably well done here.
The dev has a great knack for visually telling a story as could be also seen in his other game Beckett. 
I am now curious of what would be his next work about...

author: {'steamid': '76561198075403106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1587420250}
review:
For starters, the Gaelic text option is something i see first time so i have to mention it.
This is a visual novel. It is based on the same name adventure novel by John Buchan. You, basically, "watch" a book. It is not a game in any aspect.
The voiceovers are great and the graphics are like a painting which you would probably hang in your living room. It has a bit slow pace but it is suitable to the story.
The only negative thing i noticed is that in the tutorial it is mentioned that you advance on the story by moving your mouse in a circle clockwise but instead you can do that by just left clicking.
I enjoyed it in general, but my favorite part is the hunt and the people you meet while on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160278225', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 7868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 809, 'last_played': 1645037249}
review:
Что же представляет из себя эта игра?

The 39 Steps – это своеобразная интерактивная книга, выступающая в роли адаптации приключенческого романа шотландца Джона Бакена “39 ступеней”.

Коротко о сюжете:

Действия игры разворачиваются в Лондоне начала двадцатого века. Наш главный герой Ричард Ханней оказывается обвинен в убийстве, которого не совершал. 
И Ричарду ничего не остаётся, кроме как сбежать из города и скрываться от полиции. 
В то же время он пытается найти настоящих убийц, чтобы доказать свою правоту и добиться истины.

Геймплей:

Как и во всех визуальных новеллах, на протяжении всей игры нам придётся прочитывать текст, слушать диалоги или аудио, кликать на мышь, чтобы пролистать дальше и тд. 
Также присутствуют мини игры, например : найти вещь на сцене или рисовать мышкой фигуры, чтобы сделать конкретное действие.

Музыка и звук:

На мой взгляд, в этой игре прекрасная музыка, погружающая в атмосферу Великобритании 1914 года. 
Также на некоторых сценах есть звуки природы, звуки проезжающих машин и тд, что тоже погружает в атмосферу игры. Кроме того, немаловажным компонентом погружения игрока в этот мир является то, что есть возможность слушать диалоги и повествование на чистом английском и с акцентом шотландского.

Картинка:

От прекрасных рисованных пейзажей в «The 39 Steps» порой попросту захватывает дух. 
Все они выполнены очень и очень красиво.
Также присутствуют черно-белые вставочки а-ля старая кинохроника. 
Очень интересно то, что все персонажи выполнены в виде прозрачных расплывчатых силуэтах. 
И это очень даже необычно, ведь это заставляет нашу фантазию работать на полную катушку, чтобы представить облик героев.

Краткие итоги - 

Достоинства :

+ Прекрасный сюжет
+ Чудесное музыкальное сопровождение
+ Полное погружение в атмосферу Великобритании 1914 года
+ Красивейшие пейзажи
+ Профессиональная озвучка
+ Возможность улучшить свои знания английского
+ Легкие достижения ( Достаточно пройти игру и все достижения ваши )

Недостатки :

- Скучноватый геймплей
- Отсутствие русских субтитров
- Требуется хороший уровень владения английским, чтобы понять сюжет

The 39 Steps – очень необычная и интересная адаптация книги. 
Лично мне очень понравилась эта игра. 
Поэтому однозначно рекомендую к покупке лингвистам, любителям детективов и красивых пейзажей, а также любителям получения легких достижений в играх.

P.S.: Иногда обидно, что редко говорят о играх такого плана, как 39 Steps. 
И зря!

Главное - Это не просто обычная игра, а скорее повествующий детектив с отличными картинками и разнообразными пейзажами, где изредка, щёлкая, приходиться что-то выбирать или больше узнавать информации. 
Игра сделана по книге Джона Бакена - 39 Ступеней. 
Так же есть фильм Хичкока, который, к сожалению, мне так и не удалось посмотреть. 
Она стоит все свои 5 баксов, а сейчас даже меньше 30 - СРОЧНО БЕРИТЕ!

Игра не для всех, т.к даже с субтитрами иногда сложно разобрать почти чистый английский. 
Наикрасивейшие рисованные пейзажи, честно. Хоть бери и в рамочку вешай. Сюжет, как раз для типичных детективах, не говорю о русских.
Рекомендую, тем кто замешкался в сюжете игры, прочесть книгу.
 
Я не мог разобрать, что происходит ближе к концу и мне книга помогла. 
Отличное игра на выходные, чтобы скоротать в ней пару тройку часов, для удовольствия.
Хочу сказать, что игра не пойдет, для тех, кто вообще не любит такого жанра игры - без геймплея. 
Знание английского хотя-бы чуть выше базового. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=513477694

Моя оценка: 9 из 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198059774200', 'num_games_owned': 3215, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1586436326}
review: This visual novel provides an interesting concept, and maybe even an interesting story. It shows promise of mechanics that go over what the normal Visual Novel does. However, I did have some issues with it. It wouldn't capture my mouse, and the way to cycle through text is absolutely horrid. For the price however, this game is alright, and an interesting spin. Just keep in mind, that THIS IS A VISUAL NOVEL. Lot's of reading and story, even more so than your typical VN. If you're into it, I would buy it, but because of my fighting with the control scheme and mouse actions, I cannot recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115083039', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1565730919}
review: Ciekawa powieść multimedialna. Interaktywność jest tam wprowadzona na siłę, by móc się chwalić tym w opisie. Gra jest liniowa, nie można kontrolować tempa fabuły, przez co na początku byłem do niej zniechęcony, bo było wolne. Też niekonsekwencja w ustawieniach klawiszy dobijały (tylko przez PPM możesz wyjść do menu i potem kontynuować z ostatniego miejsca. Inne przyciski włącza ci menu, ale musisz zacząć rozdział od nowa).

author: {'steamid': '76561197989890928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1513553144}
review:
This is more story than game - all of the mechanics are simple actions to advance the story.  I hadn't read the book before playing this, but loved it so much I went and read it for myself.  It's a different experience entirely.

Even reading I could still see the points they hit on, but my own imagination goes another way reading.  The intersection only serves to enrich the experience.  If I had the ability I'd go back and do it in the same order - I played this a few years ago and still think about it all the time.

I only feel compelled to come back and review this because I was hoping these guys had done more, but alas they have not.  So I'm reviewing in the hopes that will one day happen.

Thanks for making an imprint on my life, it was truly amazing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198047498871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1584144269}
review:
Richard Hannay is a mining engineer who becomes the unlikely witness of a murder of a spy and finds himself involved in a plot to start a war between Russia and Germany. 

This interactive story is a pleasant way to live James Buchan's 1915 book in about 5 hour. I never played a game like this, with no action indee, it's both relaxing and gripping. Unlike Hitchcock's movie adaptation, it follows the original story. I don't really get the point-and-click parts, it resembles to Netflix's "Are you still there" moments. The music is fitting, but the loops are cut terribly, and the final track makes you wonder if you were watching Jason Bourne. Still, it's a very lovely thriller, and it gave me chills many times throughout the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198981428605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1744, 'last_played': 1584282959}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025854444', 'num_games_owned': 1129, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1583700585}
review:
This game is a visual novel, and I believe it would be better to just read the book.
This felt a bit stupid, since it was a bit point and click to keep the story going, and a minigame from time to time to read books, open doors, eat ect. Unnessesary for a visual novel.
I got quite annoyed at the times when you got to choose what info to read up on first. If you stil can choose to read all of it, and it's all relevant to the story, why not just make it a monolog from the main character?
Read the book instead, or get it as an audiobook. This is not a badly made visual novel, but I mostly got annoyed at the slow pacing and need to click the story onwards all the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064222599', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1583403891}
review:
Это не игра, потому что геймплея в ней нет.
Это не книга, потому что она сжата.
Это не артбук, потому что арт нельзя выбрать.
Это не визуальная новелла, потому что нет характерных для них вещей.
Это не хоррор, потому что ничего не пугает.
Это не квест, потому что не нужно думать.
Это не P&C, потому что нет Point.
Это не кликер, потому что ты тыкаешь раз в полчаса.
А что это тогда? Интерактивный пересказ? Зачем?  
По сути, это ничего. Захочу прочесть книгу - прочту настоящую. Захочу послушать аудиокнигу - послушаю настоящую. Захочу посмотреть арты - посмотрю картинки в интернете. 
Захочу поиграть в игру... пойду не сюда.

В игре нет даже оконного режима, чтобы заниматься своими вещами и иногда, когда игра даст в себя поиграть, тыкать на варианты ответа. Тем более что все диалоги там озвучены. Я, конечно, люблю ачивки, но ещё и люблю тратить время с удовольствием. Тут нет удовольствия. В этом продукте нет ничего, что я хотел бы увидеть. Эта игра была бы интереснее, если бы не пришлось тыкать кнопки вообще, самое то, чтобы уснуть.

Мой вам совет, купите за 150 рублей одноименную книгу, от неё больше пользы.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986277457', 'num_games_owned': 1327, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1624660112}

author: {'steamid': '76561198061657440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 448, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1579506330}
review: Oldukça güzel ve farklı bir görsel roman. Oyun gizemli cinayetler temalı birkaç olayı farklı bir bakış açısıyla inceliyor. Oyun olarak pek fazla birşey yapmıyorsunuz ama görsel roman oyuncuları olaya zaten hakimdir. Farklı bir hikaye okumak istiyorsanız romanından uyarlanmış olan bu oyun tam tadında diyebilirim. Oyunun güzel yanı, hikaye anlatımındaki yeniliği. Okuduğumuz karakterin neredeyse her hareketini bize yaptırması, o karakteri yaşıyor, o ortamlarda geziyormuşuz havası veriyor. Ortalama 6-8 saatlik oyun süresi bulunmakta ve orta ile iyi arasında bir ingilizceye sahip olmanız gerekmektedir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119434640', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1579384071}
review: Excellent rendition of a classic "boy's own" story. I've never played an interactive book before but I thought it was a fun format and a way to get a lot of details one tends to gloss over when reading the book in paper format. I had a lot of fun with this and the addition of voice acting and the little extras like newspaper clippings added a lot to that enjoyment. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198238011022', 'num_games_owned': 860, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1580664550}
review:
Es una novela, no se juega a nada, no nos engañemos. Hay que mover el ratón de vez en cuando, pero poco más. La historia tiene su aquel, claro... ¡porque es una novela! Sólo faltaría que encima fuese mala, pero no, al menos como lectura cumple.
Ideal para practicar inglés avanzado, eso sí, con palabros constantes que ampliarán tu vocabulario, si te molestas en traducirlos; y puedes enterarte de movidas de principio del siglo XX leyendo los múltiples e interminables periódicos que encontrarás, que oye, culturiza, ¿no? ¿Sabíais que las sufragistas iban a los museos a rajar cuadros y se cargaban las ventanas a pedradas por la calle? Yo no, pero ahora lo sé, porque leo novelas, que no va a ser todo jugar videojuegos, aunque te inciten a pensar que lo son, como éste.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026631655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1579194593}
review:
The prospect of an interactive novel sounds quite nice, and I know it's a riveting story as I have seen a theatre adaptation of it, but trying to turn it into a computer game simply does not work. The graphics aren't the most impressive, the user interface leaves some things to be desired, and when the mini games are contrived scenes as you're trying to find a few things to click and look at in a bigger scene. They also break up the flow of the story. 

When I got to the place where there is a mini game of moving the mouse in certain patterns just to open your own front door(!) I decided I had had enough.

I mean, seriously, if you are going to make a computer game, you had better make it more exciting than reading the book, but this isn't it. It completely lacks flow or coherence.

The cinematic opening titles were nice, but if I ever want to experience the 39 Steps again, I'll just read the book. It will be a lot more exciting than this "game".

author: {'steamid': '76561198186865498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1578410504}
review:
I'd never played a "visual novel" before but I did enjoy reading John Buchan's "The 39 Steps" some years ago and I've been rather disappointed with various movie adaptations, which don't stick to the source novel very well. This "game" however, does follow the novel closely and is filled the bright, airy adventure of the Scottish borders that appeals to so many fans. There's not much in the way of actual gameplay, and there's no replay value, but there's lots of atmosphere and it really does immerse you in the novel and has excellent production value. 

The game is from 2013 and the end credits (which you must watch for a bonus scene) promises more from Richard Hannay's adventures, but that has yet to come to fruition. There are 20 achievements and trading cards available.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996674071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1576802363}
review: As many of others said, it's not bad, but it's not a "Game".  If you've seen Hitchcock's film, I don't think you need to neither buy nor play this Visual Novel.  As a visual novel, it's pretty good, but there are some points of making people annoyed, like too slow transitions.  Overall, if you really love 39 Steps, it's worth to you; if not, just forgot it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110344533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1576701483}
review:
I was doubting this game at first, because all you have to do in this game is read, listen and click. It doesn't require any thinking at all. You basically read a book in a game. BUT, the intriguing story (combined with art and sound fx) made me finish the game. 

Voice acting is good enough.

There really is no replay value, but made me interested in the novel itself, so there's a chance that I will read it one day.

7/10

Not really much of a game, but I really enjoyed the plot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041115695', 'num_games_owned': 1059, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1574000916}
review:
I'm usually a massive fan of visual novel games but 39 steps commits to the "novel" aspect too much. As someone who knew nothing about the original book that the game is based on, the only way that I could get sucked into the game is with a strong opener. I could only bother getting to the second chapter as the game is brutally dry. There are small aspects of interaction such as clicking on things in the environment to get extra details about the setting and characters or do motions with your mouse to mimic the actions of the protagonist but the lack of interactivity wasn't something that I was a big fan of. If you're okay with an experience of essentially just reading a book on steam then this game is for you, but I couldn't get past the monotony and I'm throwing in the towel early.

It's not fair to rate the game overall as it might get interesting later down the line and I didn't finish it, but for people like me who want a little bit more of games like Higurashi or Danganronpa for their VNs I'd give it a pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201820504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1574035923}
review:
I hesitate to even call this an interactive novel.  There are a few times when you need to make certain gestures before you can proceed any further, but you have no real choices to make.  It's like an animated graphic novel you click through.  

I almost gave up on it in the first scene but I am glad I gave it another chance.  It was frustrating at times not to be able to click through the dialogue to speed things up, but once I gave it into the pace, I enjoyed the experience.  The illustrations are wonderful and it was interesting to see how the developers put the game together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005257487', 'num_games_owned': 1139, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1573621549}

author: {'steamid': '76561198116194964', 'num_games_owned': 3004, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1572402999}
review:
Gráficos: Eu achei os gráficos muito bonitos, as artes são bem feitas.

Efeitos sonoros: Outro ponto positivo, o jogo possui belíssimos efeitos sonoros que possibilitam uma imersão satisfatória na historia.

Música: As musicas presentes tambem possuem excelente qualidade.

Controles: É um jogo de apontar e clicar, não possui nenhum segredo.

Enredo: A historia é baseada em um livro, então basicamente é um livro interativo.

Este é um jogo simples, de apontar e clicar, que se baseia na historia do livro que possui o mesmo nome do jogo. Eu não pude jogar muito, pois ele exige do jogador um conhecimento profundo do idioma inglês. Para se ter uma experiencia no minimo razoável, você tem que ter um bom nivel de inglês, senão pode esquecer, esse jogo não é pra você.
O jogo é bem feito, eles capricharam na arte e nos efeitos sonoros, porem por eu não ter um bom nivel de ingles, logo se tornou maçante, pois não pude acompanhar a historia da forma como deveria ser.

Se você for paciente, essa também é uma excelente forma de treinar o inglês ou quem sabe tambem para esudar, nada que um bom dicionario e tempo livre não ajudem a ir até o final deste jogo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094638034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1572093861}
review:

review: Bir hikaye daha iyi nasıl anlatılır? daha ilerisi nasıl olur? roman & hikaye kitapları oyunlaştırılarak görsel hafızayla beyinde daha iyi nasıl canlandırılarak anlatılır? hikayeleri çocuklara okutmak yerine oyunlarla oynatarak anlatımla özellikle görsel açıdan ses çevre etkileşimi(bu oyunda çok fazla olmasada) ile beyinde daha farklı bir şekilde canlandırarak gelişimine katkı sağlanabilir? sorularına cevap niteliğinde bir oyun. piskolokların, pedagogların, bazı hastanelerde açılan oyun bağımlılığı saçmalığı bölümünde çalışan yan gelip yatan doktor adı altında ne iş yaptığını bile bilmeyen sağlıkmı okmuş rehber öğretmenliğimi okumuş tam ne olduğu belirsiz insanlara, oyunları aptal çocuklar insanlar oynar, oyun oynayanlar beyinsizdir kafaları hiçbir şeyi basmaz diyenleri oturtup bu oyunu oynatmak lazım. oyunların hurele gürele pat küt vur kaç kır olmadığını anlamaları için. sadece ingilizce desteği var malesef Türkçe dil desteği yok orta derece ingilizceyle anlamaya çalıştığım kadarıyla harika güzel bir eser ortaya çıkmış. O saçma sapan ders kitaplarına "A noktası sizi B noktasına yok halay sizi her yere götürür" böyle saçma sapan şeyler okutulcağına bu oyunu alıp ders kitaplarında okutsalar çocuklarda yeni düşünceler fikirler ortaya çıkar. herkes bu oyunu oynamalı alın oynayın oynatın oynattırın.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188664927', 'num_games_owned': 1601, 'num_reviews': 385, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1562896351}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AfHUDRVYiVk&list=PLIb_a695uFXCXLgbEdkcPWNlDB2jZ8U4A&index=2
[h1] Game Summary: [/h1] 
Apparently, this is a game recreation of a book by the same name, written back in 1915 by John Buchan.  I looked into the story more after finishing the game, and people seem rather captivated by it, as it's been made into a few movie adaptations and a play.  This may stem more from how this was the theoretical first story centered around fleeing from the police and ne'er-do-wells, which is now a fairly popular sub-genre of thriller movie (man on the run).  


If you're like me though, you never heard of anything about this story in any form before seeing this game.  I'll admit that I'm not really sure what motivated anyone to take a novel and make a game out of it.  In essence, it's simply a visual novel, with a small scattering of things for you to interact with, as you progress through the story.  Seemingly it's so much like other visual novels that one would think it'd be perfectly fine, but I'm not sure that it succeeded overall.  


[h1] Pros: [/h1] 
	• The accompanying background music seems well-suited for the story and game.  I can't speak with any expertise as to whether it's period-specific though.  
	• I appreciated the inclusion of black and white photographs of people to give more life and authenticity to the era of the game.  
	• The text was clear and large enough to be easily read by most people.  
	• May scratch an itch for devoted fans of this story or older literature.


[h1] Cons: [/h1] 
	• Infrequently, the game puts in a few sections where you have to move the mouse in specific ways, following a pattern, in order to complete an action and progress.  This may have helped break up the monotony if it were used more often, or for more interesting actions, but the most common use of this mechanic was to open doors.  It's so unusual that it's more hilarious than engaging or interesting.  
	• In the tutorial, the game instructs you to rotate the mouse to either advance or scroll back through the text.  However, you can actually just click the left mouse button to advance text, as would be expected.  The game doesn't tell you this though; I only found out by accident.
	• Characters aren't actually given a full image.  Aside from a small scattering of black and white photographs, you never get to see what Hannay or anyone else looks like, other than as a vague silhouette.  The VN is short-changing you on the visuals.  
	• Some of the driest parts I had to read through were the newspaper clippings.  They really dragged the pace down with uninteresting text bombs.  
	• Occasionally, certain areas of the game are voice-acted, but I never saw any sense on what parts were or weren't.  
	• I don't think the story is very well-written, and I didn't like the protagonist.


[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 
I'll always acknowledge that VN games don't tend to be my cup of tea, but I think this one was doomed to failure from the start.  For those who'd want to read so much already, they may as well pick up the original novel and go through it the old-fashioned way.  Others would have the option to watch one of the movie adaptations, which provides much more stimulus, without the need for actively scrolling through so much text.  Even if creative liberties need to be taken for it to be film-friendly, deviating from the story somewhat, I'd have much rather simply watched a movie version of this instead.  The medium of a VN provided me no comparative benefit to observing this story another way, meaning the five hours I spent going through the game could have been spent on watching a couple of the movies.  There's no reason for me to recommend this game, when retelling this 100 year old story has been done better elsewhere.

Gameplay wise there's not much to do beside some mouse movement and soundwise everything is simply ok.

If you don't like to read books but are curious of the 39 steps's story, this is a good replacement for it.

As a game it has little to offer but as a visual novel it does his job right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037839153', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1469861287}
review:
[h1]RECENZJA RETROSPEKCYJNA[/h1]

[b]Coś tu NIE-GRA[/b]
Po pierwsze nijak nie można tego tworu - jak i jego elementów - nazwać grą. Owszem zawiera on mechaniki które angażują gracza wymagając od niego wykonania prostych czynności ale to są jedynie zabiegi wyrywające z monotonii przeklikiwania kolejnych stron wirtualnej opowieści. A szkoda.
[b]Klawa historia bracie[/b]
Samo przedstawienie tej historii w taki sposób jest co najmniej ciekawe. Elementy graficzne grają ze sobą znakomicie, narracja jak i całe udźwiękowienie jest spójne i przyjemne dla ucha. To ewidentny plus.
[b]NIEnajdłuższa podróż[/b]
Choć zgodnie z opisem powinna wystarczyć na 5-8 godz. to ja skończyłem całość w 3.7 godz. To za mało zwłaszcza gdy za cenę tego produktu kupuję tradycyjną książkę która wystarcza mi na przynajmniej 10 godz.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055531472', 'num_games_owned': 1179, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1560586087}
review:
[h1] Long Winded, A Game Only A Fan Could Love	[/h1]
So I know what thrillers are, it's a genre I really enjoy. This... well I'm just going to call it what it is. It's a kinetic novel, not a game. You don't make choices or do anything really. The only interactions the game gives you is clicking or rotating your mouse through text (a strange choice), occasionally he'll stop and you can click on a few things in the room to look closer at them or read them if you'd like to, then there's the odd rotating your mouse or pushing it forward to open a door or box for no reason other than interactivity. 

A fan of the books would love this game, the details go above and beyond to the point where you can read every word of every newspaper if you'd like to. There's also a ton of unnecessary details that the player doesn't, will never need to know, and will forget after playing. It's clear that a fan of the novels made this "game", but they took no consideration for people that have never read the books. If you're coming in blind then it's not thrilling in the slightest, it's long winded and doesn't know a quote I enjoy a lot, "A conversation should be like a short skirt. Long enough to cover the important bits, but short enough to leave them wanting more." This is a good philosophy for story telling too. The reader or in this case player needs a reason to stick around, and they simply don't give you one.

If your a fan of the source material, go nuts, I'm sure you'll have a wonderful time. A newcomer won't find much for themselves here though.

[h1] Pros:	[/h1]
+Mechanics and format that a lot of visual novels could benefit from
+In-depth Detail that fans would love
+A lot of voice acting that isn't bad at all

[h1] Cons:	[/h1]
-Long winded, it doesn't keep you engaged or wanting more
-Not thrilling at all
-Pointless interactivity just for the sake of being interactive
-A lot of the times it wouldn't let me click to go forward on the dialog, I don't know if it has trouble switching between cutscenes and kinetic novel but it liked to tell me no when trying to advance through dialog. If you can't control how fast you're moving through the dialog then there's no point in letting you control it at all. There were many times that I could read a line 8 times over before it let me advance in the text.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975760979', 'num_games_owned': 1239, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1642282452}
review:
This is a hard game to describe, mainly because it isn't really a game, it's like a book you sometimes interact with.
I for one have heard of the book but never read it so this was a great way to expierence the book as it has everything you need in an espionage, spies, murder and intrigue, I can see why it is an often talked about novel.
It's a great gaming expierence and is a must for anyone who likes a game to be a bit cerebal, if your into COD, you may not like this game but if you like an engaging story delivered in a modern way, you will love this.
I have only two small gripes , it sometimes takes a bit to work out what you have to do , which can start off frustrating but percieve with it as you will be thankful you have but why does pressing the right mouse button ( the expected action button ) have to take you out of the game , this does kill the expierence at times which meant I started using my left hand to stop myself doing this, but with something as good as this and the incredible attention to detail , the developers can be forgiven even if they should of play tested this out.
If I had to score it , it would be an 8 that would of been a 9 with the two niggles removed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052473182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1559469687}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026048770', 'num_games_owned': 6129, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1559429366}
review:
This is a digital retelling of a classic novel, with fewer gameplay choices than visual novels. It won't be to everyone's taste but it superbly translates the reading experience to the medium in a stylish manner that has its own unique charm. 

The artwork, voice acting, and storytelling are well done, if a bit slow-paced for modern readers/gamers/viewers. The story itself is something of the fore-father to modern thrillers and inspired Ian Flemming's early James Bond novels. It is, however, a much slower burn than modern adventure tales or espionage thrillers, with more in common with the delivery we find in tales of Sherlock Holmes. It took me a bit to get into the flow of it but I'm glad to have had the experience.  

I'd have almost certainly never absorbed this work of fiction had it not been for this digital recreation. In an age where there's more entertainment at our fingertips than any human could consume in a hundred lifetimes, this proves to be an effective, if imperfect, means of capturing the essence of a classic and distilling it in enjoyable, convenient way. I would love to see more novels converted to the gaming medium like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025089345', 'num_games_owned': 2174, 'num_reviews': 2932, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1558934664}
review:
<三十九级台阶> 英文点击类游戏~
似乎不用看懂英文~直接点点点也能通关游戏~

author: {'steamid': '76561198030280204', 'num_games_owned': 2173, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1558152541}
review:
I enjoyed this game a lot, but just so you know what you're getting into - this isn't so much a game as it is a guided retelling of this story. You will spend most of your time looking and beautiful scenery and clicking to advance the lines of text (there is supposedly some feature where you spin your mouse to advance the story but that was not working for me at all). Every so often, you'll hear two (or more) characters exchange dialogue, you'll watch a flashback vignette, or be asked to swirl your mouse around to open doors, eat food, etc. All of these serve to immerse you in the story, and they work well, just don't understand that there is absolutely zero player agency in this game.

One thing I will point out is that many games will "dress up" a story on rails by trying to convince the player they're in the scene by finding interaction points, choosing dialogue options, etc - but The 39 Steps doesn't waste time with that. There is stuff to investigate, but they will clearly highlight it on the screen. And when you're shown a full page of a newspaper, there is a button to click that will highlight the relevant part of the story for you. That was much appreciated and helped to keep the game from getting tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044916804', 'num_games_owned': 1831, 'num_reviews': 484, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1462055800}

author: {'steamid': '76561198259789863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1553368833}
review:
"The only thing to distrust is the normal."

Apparently, this game is based on James Buchanan's 1915 novel of the same name, which also influenced the James Bond series. Go figure. I've never read the novel, but maybe I'll give it a whirl someday. Regardless, I enjoy a good piece of interactive fiction from time to time, and I feel like I got what I was looking for with The 39 Steps.

Being more of a visual novel, you can expect to do quite a bit of reading; however, that's made enjoyable by the eye-catching graphics/art style, excellent voice acting, and lovely soundtrack. From walking around foggy London streets to hiking through the Scottish countryside, the music and art combine to really enhance the overall mood. Aside from the reading, most of the game's action sequences revolve around relatively simple scene searches and mouse movements. The latter can feel a bit silly, especially when you're just going through the motions to open a door or something, but it's what you'd expect from a visual novel so I wasn't particularly annoyed. Each scene is also relatively short, which offers the player a break from the "action" (reading).

Definitely recommended for fans of this genre: those who appreciate visual novels, graphic adaptations of novels, etc. I enjoyed The 39 Steps and will probably play it again someday, much like picking up an enjoyable book for another read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083246187', 'num_games_owned': 750, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1555603403}
review:
[i]The 39 Steps[/i] is one of those video games that many will insist isn't a video game. Perhaps more appropriately categorized as a visual novel, it tells a very solid story through on-screen text, narration, dialogue, and artwork in a surprisingly varied amount of styles.

While the main gameplay interaction is simply pressing the right arrow key to cycle lines of text (*see note below), this is broken up with occasional variations on point-and-click, such as scanning newspaper articles, selecting objects in a room, and drawing shapes with the mouse. If it sounds basic and uninteresting, well, it is - but that's not the point of the game. These mechanics only serve to add a bit of spice to the main intent of this experience, which is to sit back, relax, and enjoy a good story.

It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but the plot of [i]The 39 Steps[/i] is well crafted, adapted from a novel written in 1915 by a Scottish author named John Buchan. It follows a simple three act structure, where the main character unwittingly gets tangled up in a political conspiracy, goes on the run from his enemies, and eventually tries to gain the upper hand. Richard Hannay, the protagonist and narrator, is crafty and intelligent, and it's a pleasure to witness how he handles several very dangerous situations through quick thinking and improvisation. Although the pace of the story feels slow due to the calm cadence of its text, it actually moves at a pretty brisk pace, covering a novel's worth of events in the span of about 3 hours. I imagine much of the writing from the book was copied verbatim here, albeit heavily abridged to serve the pace of a game. This is not an edge-of-your-seat thriller, but it's nevertheless an entertaining ride - perfect for a quiet evening or two at home with a cup of tea, enjoyed the same way one would enjoy a good book.

I won't include spoilers here, but my only complaint with the story is its ending - I am again assuming this is kept true to the novel. Story structure was much different 100 years ago, and the third act builds intrigue and mystery in a way that today's standards would demand some sort of interesting twist or confrontation but ultimately falls very flat, followed by an abrupt ending that offers no closure to the characters involved. It's a heavy dud at the end of an otherwise enjoyable tale.

The game's best feature is its historical setting - taking place in 1914 in wartime Europe, the writing and dialogue reflect a strong grasp on the English language as it was used and written at that time, delivered with some superb voice acting. All of the artwork is again period-accurate, mostly delivered in the format of painted stills of European environments in both the city and countryside. Although character art exists in the game, most scenes show people as silhouettes - this is to the game's benefit, since the real focus is on the voice work.

Similar to novels like Mark Danielewski's [i]House of Leaves[/i], the way the text is presented sometimes follows the on-screen action, adding to the drama of a scene in a minimalistic way. Animation is effective where it needs to be. And even though most scenes are composed of stills, there is a vibrant and lively sound effects track present throughout, emphasizing scenes with soundscapes like a bustling train station or a gentle river in a farming village, layered with surprisingly well-arranged music.

This isn't the type of game that can ever hope to receive a showering of praise from today's gaming audience. It's a small-scale, small-budget interactive novel that only takes a few hours to complete. But what it sets out to do it succeeds in doing very admirably. If you enjoy reading novels, there is a good chance you will appreciate the tone and pacing of this interactive story. Were it to have a more fulfilling ending, I would have considered it a near-perfect experience.

*If you are planning on trying this game out, I recommend you ignore the default control tutorial, which has you cycling through text with mouse circles. I found this method unwieldy bordering on broken, and I highly recommend you scroll by using the keyboard arrows.

review:
[h1]BORING[/h1]
I'm fine with "games" that are just digital books with no challenge or choices. But this is boring and looks cheap, with lots of prattling on about old timey England. This was obviously made (on a tiny budget) by fans of The 39 Steps novel/movies and maybe this is worth playing if you're a big fan too, but otherwise it's barely a step up from the terrible games that people gift each on Steam as a joke. If you're tempted by this I would suggest trying [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/381780/80_Days/]80 Days[/url] instead - its writers actually understood the importance of brevity!

author: {'steamid': '76561198074314134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1547109290}
review:
I was very disappointed with this game. They make it sound like it's going to be a very interesting story - a thriller! Inspiration for James Bond! - but it's an absolute bore, and I'm someone who loves reading lots of different genres of novels. Overall, I found the story to be confusing, slow paced, and predictable, and for a "game" that is literally just clicking through text after text after text, it needs to have an amazing and immersive story to make it worthwhile.

Graphics of the scenery were nice, but that's about all I can compliment. The voiceovers were okay but a lot of them had accents that were difficult to understand, with subtitles that were no help. There were parts of the story (usually the dreadful Scottish accents!) that I had no idea what was going on, thanks to the accents and use of dated language. The only "interactive" part of the "game" was doing some different movements with the mouse (to do things like open a door...) so you're not constantly clicking or rotating clockwise to progress the text. It took me three hours to complete, which I had to do in several sittings as I kept on getting bored while waiting for something exciting to happen, and there were no missable achievements.

I don't like to leave a negative review, but I wish I hadn't wasted my time on this game. I feel like the summary is a bit misleading and I wanted to leave a negative review to give potential buyers a different take on it, as the summary and positive reviews lead me to buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025812458', 'num_games_owned': 1977, 'num_reviews': 445, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1549352103}
review:
Admittedly I haven't watched The 39 Steps directed by Alfred Hitchcock, nor have I read the original novel by John Buchan. Either way, I'm gonna go out on a limb and say that this adaptation by The Story Mechanics is not the most worthwhile version of the story. The pacing here is tragically slow. The transitions and interactive elements are also just mundane. So essentially everything that would make this adaptation on Steam worthwhile doesn't really impress me that much. 

If you want to experience The 39 Steps, I think you could find a better paced and more interesting story in either the novel or the film. This interactive visual novel is modern but uninteresting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972465344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1546305644}
review:
So, this "Digital Adaptation" of a novel, as they call it, is an interesting beast. The story itself, which is the main point of a visual novel, is good, as would be expected as it is based on a real novel.

That being said, since there is not much gameplay involved, the judgement of this "game" is then mostly on the technical execution side. Let's just go through my experience:

I launch the game, and dreadully I notice that it goes into full screen mode using 1920x1080 resolution, downsizing the desktop from the native 3840x2160, causing all open previously windows, Steam included, to be moved and resized. So the first thing in the main menu I am looking for graphics options to change the resolution, in vain. A bit upset of this setback, I start the story.

The game starts with a kind of a tutorial on the controls, telling to make a clockwise motion with mouse to progress on the text, and use left mouse click to progress at the end of a scene. A bit awkward way to do it. Then it explains that the game is mostly pointer-free and that if you see the mouse cursor, that's the cue that it's time to interact with it. And the first scene is to click on your Apartment to go in there.

At this point, since the wrong resolution is taking away the enjoyment already, I hit Escape in hopes of a in-game menu that might contains some settings to fix it. Instead, it brings a menu containing Events, Cards, Bookmarks, and Extras. I click through them but don't find any options to change the resolution, so in the Events screen I see one tile is unlocked, presuming that to be the start of the game, so I click on that, and choose to Play. Apparently doing that just skipped the rest of the tutorial and went directly to the first chapter of the actual story. Later I find out that completing the tutorial would yield one of the in-game awards, and there is no way to get back to the tutorial. So thanks, trying to fix a technical issue just permanently banned me from getting one unlockable on this profile. Whatever, let's continue the story.

Despite having missed the tutorial, I quickly learn the rest of the game mechanics, how to interact with objects, and how the story plays out. Not really a fan of the mouse movement to progress on text, I try to figure out alternative ways to progress and find out that simply clicking the left mouse button appears to do the same as the mouse movement, but unlike waving with the mouse, it also works for the end of the scene, for what it was for instructed in the tutorial. Still, not keen on keeping my hand on the mouse all the time for a game that's mostly about reading text, I tried pressing Enter (or Return, as they call it) and that seemed to work too!

Except, at some points I notice that if I press Enter, the game doesn't just progress to the next piece of text, but totally skips the scene. This seemed random to me, and there was even a part where using keyboard didn't progress forward but mouse click did. Too bad that the game is about the text, and this made me miss some of it! I didn't see an easy way to go back. Also, because of this random scene-skipping, I encountered a bug that after the end of an Event, skipping the final scene caused the event completion achievement not unlocking, and also the next Event tile stayed locked and black, even though the story itself progressed forward. Funnily, at the end of the game I got the achievement for completing all the events, even though one event completion achievement was still locked due to this bug!

At some point I had to Alt-Tab out of the game. On first try it worked all fine, just with the inconvenience of resolution switching back and forth, causing window sizing and scaling problems, but on the next try the game just froze and I couldn't go back in. Fortunately the progress is auto-saved constantly, so no progress was lost. At this point I went through the Steam Discussion for the game and found out that you can change the in-game screen resolution by editing Windows Registry. A bit cumbersome for such a basic setting, but at least I managed to make the game run with the native resolution now.

Also later on I found out that in the Extra menu there is a section explaining the controls, and there it says that Left and Right arrow keys are aliases for the mouse-controlled text progression, and Return is for skipping the scene. So it was somehow my fault for not finding this information first and only learning the hard way to refrain from reading the text using Enter (as it didn't always skip the whole scene...!) Also in the Controls section it told me that Backspace goes back to previous scene. Oh would that also have been handy to know at the times I mistakenly skipped something. I wonder why the keyboard controls weren't mentioned at all during the tutorial? (yes, I did then replay the tutorial with different player profile to see how that part goes through)

At least I managed to get all the Steam achievements, thanks to the ability to jump back to any scene from the Events menu, so I jumped back to the end of the event where I bug-skipped the ending, to unlock the last thing. Still I am missing some of the in-game unlockables for this profile, including the tutorial completion, which apparently is impossible to get if you happen to skip it by mistake. Normally I would go replay a game to unlock the rest of the collectibles, and in this case to read the scenes I missed because of non-explained controls, but the way the story is told is putting me off.

The actual story text is not that plentiful, to tell what's happening with the protagonist, usually a few sentences per scene, but then all the unnecessary text, such as newspaper articles that have nothing to do with the plot, can have many pages of text to be read. I would have expected the opposite, and would have loved to read more of the feelings and environment, as I presume would have been the case in the original text novel. I am only guessing that the authors of the game tried to minimize the text to the reader, and use the artwork to replace much of the environmental description.

So, since the way the story was presented was suboptimal, and due to all the technical issues that would have been basic to fix, I cannot recommend the game as it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067941108', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1562257070}
review:
I find it hard to recommend this. This is not a game, it is an interactive audio book, with the "interactions" consisting of some really weak attempts to engage the player beyond just clicking ahead for the next line of text to appear.
The art style is simplistic and often feels half finished or rushed, which sucks when the semi pretty pictures makes up almost your entire experience listening to the story. 
Based on the novel by John Buchan writen in 1915, the story reads like a old timely spy thriller radio play, and is interesting enough once you get into it. 
Voice acting is good, with some hilarious british gentleman action and some frankly unintelligible scottish accents. 
The music is used effectively to create some tension but only during a handful of infrequent moments. 
This game simply lack any interesting ideas and should have looked way more detailed.
Get it cheap.

CLEARTIME: Around 4 hours to 100% with no missable achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079494546', 'num_games_owned': 1185, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1544727980}
review:
Its a visual novel, where you have absolutely no choice whatsoever, just a spectator of the story. I felt that I'm Stanley from The Stanley Parable, clicking where I have to...

Cons:
- The bad part is that the story is nowhere close to good, every action has little to no consequence on the hero.
- Too bad they decided to use siluettes as characters, it tore away the personalities of them.
- Its unnecessarily slow, it kept me waiting for too long between cutscenes
- The chapter menu came out after every chapter (so every ~12 minutes)

Pro:
+ The voice acting was mostly good
+ The dialects was on point (I'm glad that the subtitle kept it fonetic, so you still barely understand it)
+ The art was decent
+ The subtitle was creatively put on the screen

author: {'steamid': '76561198091030601', 'num_games_owned': 807, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1394, 'last_played': 1544372029}
review:
The original novel written by Scottish author John Buchan in 1915 and is a classic piece of modern literature.  Hitchcock did a stunning film based upon it in 1935.  Dating the story is important in appreciating the game itself.  The game pays tribute in both its artistic style and dialogue to its roots.  Rich watercolors make the background quite enjoyable.  The voice acting feels authentic for the period being presented.  

I believe I received The 39 Steps as part of a bundle.  I would not personally pay full price for it.  It does not take very long to complete and I'd classify it more as a visual novel than a game.  The "puzzles" are nothing more than mimicking a few strokes, the plot is completely linear.  The UI suggests making some sweeping circles of the mouse to go forward/back that don't work quite as intended as some other reviewers have noted.

Still, I am going to recommend this game.  I wouldn't pay more than $5 for it personally, so I advocate waiting for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013224267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1514676698}
review:
[h1] ✧･ﾟ: *✧･ﾟ:*    A click-through adventure novel   *:･ﾟ✧*:･ﾟ✧[/h1]

An adaptation of a historical adventure thriller, The 39 Steps is best enjoyed slowly, as it really offers no choices but plays more like an audiobook that matches your pace. The characters appear only as silhouettes, which seems hard to keep track of but nevertheless works effectively, allowing for the same expressive imagination as reading a book. There are several instances where the protagonist engages in investigation of his surroundings, which will manifest as close-ups to crime scenes or post Edwardian-era inspired newspaper clippings. The game is not terribly long, overall, but it struck just the right amount for me as I had been getting anxious to finish towards the denouement. 

[h1]✧･ﾟ: *✧･ﾟ:* 　PROS　 *:･ﾟ✧*:･ﾟ✧[/h1]

❧ Fantastic voice acting - very clever use of dialects all over the UK, and the fluidity of some characters' abilities to switch between accents really brings the feeling of a spy thriller to life. Really, worth it for this alone if you wait for a sale.

❧ Feels appropriate for the period, and takes an interesting approach into a believable, slightly alternate history.

❧ Decent variety of environments. Some are hand-drawn, others are stock photos with some photo effects to mask them. Nothing really stands out, but it's not unpleasant to look at for hours. Often very pretty, better than most cartoon styles in my opinion.

❧ Fairly atmospheric, between the sound effects, music and constant feeling of danger and mistrust. 

❧ I appreciate the writing and that the descriptive text tends to be much better than most visual novels - again, likely because this is an adaptation.

❧ Occasionally very thrilling - some scenes gripped me so much, paired with sound effects, that I really felt compelled to see the chapters through.


[h1]✧･ﾟ: *✧･ﾟ:* CONS *:･ﾟ✧*:･ﾟ✧[/h1]

❧ The protagonist, Richard Hannay, is completely odious and unlikeable in my opinion. He can be said to have a personality, at the very least, even if it is arrogant and entitled. It's tolerable, but mostly I feel I have to bear through him to appreciate the rest of the story.

❧ Periodically very tedious, even for the patient. Some scenes are unskippable, text speed and transitions are slow. Don't rush through. Enjoy it with a cup of tea, or you won't enjoy it at all.

❧ Perhaps it is because the game must necessarily lack the same depth as the book, the last half-hour felt distinctly unsatisfying, underscored largely because (endgame spoiler) [spoiler]the protagonist spends an egregious amount of time doubting something that should be obvious[/spoiler], although it does fit well enough into the spy theme. It just felt like a very slow end to an otherwise more exciting pace. [spoiler]Then again, the narrative always indicates that we should trust nothing, and such misdirections and disguises happen all throughout.[/spoiler]

[h1]✧･ﾟ: *✧･ﾟ:* CONCLUSIONS *:･ﾟ✧*:･ﾟ✧[/h1]

Likely not for everyone, including those who typically like visual novels. Still, it is a nice change of pace from the typical anime style on Steam, and at times thrilling enough to make me want to take a look at the original book.

author: {'steamid': '76561198344028004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1543451937}
review: 39 Steps é uma espécie de livro digital. Não há escolhas ou possibilidade de alternar o caminho da história, mas apenas de seguir adiante. Os gráficos são bons, mas todos extáticos. Achei interessante o que nãovou classificar como jogo mas como  uma maneira bastante original de ler um livro. A história é boa e está vinculada à primeira guerra mundial.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078278016', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1542055794}
review:
So, this is something you can enjoy, but calling it a game is a bit of a stretch. Its strongest point is the story, but the story is based on a novel written over 100 years ago, so that's not exactly a compliment to the production of this game.

The "gameplay" is to a great degree a very passive and patience-testing experience. There is virtually zero animation and the text and scene transitions are slow. The game is minimally interactive and feels dead. They also tried to reinvent the wheel with the UI a little bit. Thankfully, everything was divided into chapters, which made it easier to play and finish. I suggest we add a new tag called "Patience Training" just for the sake of this game.

Also, giving out 100% achievements just for playing the game is very dull and unimaginative.

But nevertheless, if one can look past all this, overall the game did manage to have a good enough atmosphere (the voice acting and sound design were superb) and to leave a memorable impression. Having completed it, I can say that I have a fond memory of it and that I would play it again. But I would play it again in the same way I would read a book again, so it's actually a very confusing feeling.
